title: Isolation Precautions & PPE Quiz
description: Comprehensive quiz covering isolation precautions, personal protective equipment, and infection prevention practices

questions.question: Standard precautions should be applied to:
options: All patients in all healthcare settings
questions.explanation: Standard precautions are the foundation of infection prevention and should be applied to all patients in all healthcare settings.

questions.question: Contact precautions require:
questions.explanation: Contact precautions require both gloves and gown to prevent transmission of organisms through direct contact or contact with contaminated surfaces.

questions.question: Droplet precautions are used for organisms transmitted by:
questions.explanation: Droplet precautions are for organisms transmitted by large respiratory droplets (>5 microns) that travel short distances.

questions.question: Airborne precautions require:
questions.explanation: Airborne precautions require N95 respirator or higher level respiratory protection to filter small airborne particles.

questions.question: Hand hygiene should be performed:
options: Only when hands are visibly soiled
questions.explanation: Hand hygiene should be performed before and after patient contact as part of the WHO 5 Moments for Hand Hygiene.

questions.question: PPE should be removed in which order:
questions.explanation: PPE removal order: gloves first (most contaminated), then gown, eye protection, and mask/respirator last.

questions.question: A private room is required for:
questions.explanation: Private rooms are required for airborne precautions. Contact and droplet precautions prefer private rooms but allow cohorting.

questions.question: Negative pressure rooms are required for:
questions.explanation: Negative pressure rooms (AIIRs) are required for airborne precautions to prevent airborne organisms from escaping the room.

questions.question: Eye protection is required for:
questions.explanation: Eye protection is required when splashing of blood, body fluids, secretions, or excretions is anticipated.

questions.question: Alcohol-based hand rub is NOT effective against:
questions.explanation: Alcohol-based hand rub is not effective against C. difficile spores; soap and water handwashing is required.

questions.question: MRSA requires which type of precautions?
questions.explanation: MRSA requires contact precautions (gloves and gown) in addition to standard precautions due to transmission through direct contact or contaminated surfaces.

questions.question: Tuberculosis (TB) requires:
questions.explanation: Active pulmonary TB requires airborne precautions with N95 respirator or PAPR in an airborne infection isolation room (AIIR) with negative pressure.

questions.question: VRE (Vancomycin-Resistant Enterococcus) requires:
questions.explanation: VRE requires contact precautions due to transmission through direct contact with patients or contaminated environmental surfaces.

questions.question: Influenza requires which precautions?
questions.explanation: Seasonal influenza requires droplet precautions (surgical mask within 6 feet) due to transmission through large respiratory droplets.

questions.question: CRE (Carbapenem-Resistant Enterobacteriaceae) requires:
questions.explanation: CRE requires contact precautions due to transmission through direct contact and contaminated equipment. Enhanced barrier precautions may be needed during outbreaks.

questions.question: Measles requires which precautions?
questions.explanation: Measles is highly contagious and requires airborne precautions with N95 respirator due to transmission through small airborne particles that remain suspended in air.

questions.question: Scabies requires:
questions.explanation: Scabies requires contact precautions due to transmission through direct skin-to-skin contact. Crusted (Norwegian) scabies requires enhanced contact precautions.

questions.question: COVID-19 requires which precautions in healthcare settings?
options: Contact and droplet precautions with eye protection
questions.explanation: COVID-19 requires contact and droplet precautions with eye protection. N95 respirator is required for aerosol-generating procedures.

questions.question: Norovirus requires:
questions.explanation: Norovirus requires contact precautions due to transmission through fecal-oral route and contaminated surfaces. Environmental cleaning with bleach is essential.

questions.question: Pertussis (whooping cough) requires:
questions.explanation: Pertussis requires droplet precautions due to transmission through large respiratory droplets during coughing. Precautions continue until 5 days of appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.question: A patient with MRSA pneumonia and C. difficile diarrhea requires:
options: Contact precautions with soap and water hand hygiene
questions.explanation: Both MRSA and C. difficile require contact precautions. C. difficile spores require soap and water handwashing instead of alcohol-based hand rub.

questions.question: During aerosol-generating procedures on a COVID-19 patient, you should wear:
options: N95 respirator, gown, gloves, eye protection
questions.explanation: Aerosol-generating procedures (intubation, bronchoscopy, suctioning) require N95 respirator or PAPR, gown, gloves, and eye protection due to increased aerosol generation.

questions.question: A patient with suspected TB has a negative pressure room unavailable. What is the BEST alternative?
options: Place in private room with door closed and N95 for all entering
questions.explanation: If AIIR unavailable, place patient in private room with door closed, use N95 respirators for all entering, and transfer to facility with AIIR as soon as possible.

questions.question: When can contact precautions be discontinued for MRSA colonization?
questions.explanation: Contact precautions for MRSA can be discontinued after 3 negative surveillance cultures from previously positive sites, taken at least 1 week apart, per facility policy.

questions.question: A patient with varicella (chickenpox) requires:
questions.explanation: Varicella requires both airborne precautions (respiratory transmission) and contact precautions (direct contact with lesions). Immune healthcare workers may provide care.

questions.question: PPE donning sequence should be:
questions.explanation: Correct donning sequence: gown first, then mask/respirator, then eye protection, then gloves last (to cover gown cuffs).

questions.question: A patient with disseminated herpes zoster requires:
questions.explanation: Disseminated (or localized in immunocompromised) herpes zoster requires airborne and contact precautions until lesions are crusted. Localized zoster in immunocompetent patients requires contact precautions only.

questions.question: N95 respirator fit testing should be performed:
options: Annually and when changing respirator model
Only if the user requests it
questions.explanation: N95 fit testing is required annually, when changing respirator model/size, and after significant facial changes (weight loss/gain, dental work, facial surgery).

questions.question: A patient with MDRO (multi-drug resistant organism) in a wound requires:
questions.explanation: MDROs (MRSA, VRE, CRE, MDRO Acinetobacter, MDRO Pseudomonas) require contact precautions to prevent transmission through direct contact or contaminated surfaces.

questions.question: When caring for a patient on contact precautions, dedicated equipment should:
options: Be used and left in the room or cleaned/disinfected before use on another patient
Only be used for airborne precautions
questions.explanation: Dedicated equipment (stethoscope, BP cuff, thermometer) should remain in the room or be cleaned and disinfected with EPA-registered disinfectant before use on another patient.

questions.question: During a CRE outbreak, enhanced barrier precautions include:
options: Contact precautions with dedicated staff and equipment
questions.explanation: CRE outbreaks require enhanced barrier precautions: contact precautions, dedicated staff/equipment, active surveillance cultures, cohorting, and enhanced environmental cleaning.

questions.question: A patient with suspected viral hemorrhagic fever (Ebola) requires:
options: Contact and droplet precautions with eye protection
Contact, droplet, and airborne precautions with PAPR
questions.explanation: Viral hemorrhagic fevers require strict isolation with contact, droplet, and airborne precautions using PAPR, impermeable gown, double gloves, and dedicated trained staff.

questions.question: Cohorting patients during an outbreak means:
options: Grouping patients with same organism together with dedicated staff
Mixing all patients regardless of infection
questions.explanation: Cohorting groups patients infected with the same organism together (geographic or by dedicated staff) when private rooms are limited, preventing cross-transmission to uninfected patients.

questions.question: A healthcare worker with active TB should:
options: Be placed on medical leave until non-infectious
Work only in non-patient care areas
questions.explanation: Healthcare workers with active TB must be placed on medical leave until they are non-infectious (3 negative sputum smears, clinical improvement, at least 2 weeks of appropriate therapy).

questions.question: During a norovirus outbreak, environmental cleaning should use:
questions.explanation: Norovirus requires EPA-registered disinfectants with norovirus claims or bleach at 1,000-5,000 ppm (1:50 to 1:10 dilution). Alcohol and quats are not effective against norovirus.

questions.question: A patient with suspected novel respiratory pathogen requires:
options: Contact, droplet, and airborne precautions until transmission mode clarified
Wait for CDC guidance before implementing precautions
questions.explanation: For novel pathogens with unknown transmission, use precautionary approach with contact + droplet + airborne precautions until transmission mode is clarified through epidemiologic investigation.

questions.question: PAPR (Powered Air-Purifying Respirator) is preferred over N95 for:
options: Prolonged care of airborne precaution patients or when N95 fit test fails
questions.explanation: PAPR is preferred for prolonged care of airborne precaution patients, when N95 fit test fails, for healthcare workers with facial hair, or during high-risk aerosol-generating procedures.

questions.question: Active surveillance cultures for MDRO should be performed on:
options: High-risk patients (ICU, prior MDRO, transfers from high-prevalence facilities)
No patients, surveillance cultures are not useful
questions.explanation: Active surveillance cultures target high-risk patients: ICU admissions, prior MDRO history, transfers from high-prevalence facilities, or during outbreaks to identify colonized patients early.

questions.question: A patient with C. difficile infection should remain on contact precautions until:
options: Discharge or 48 hours after diarrhea resolution, whichever is longer
questions.explanation: Contact precautions for C. difficile continue until discharge or at least 48 hours after diarrhea resolution, whichever is longer. Do not test for cure as patients may remain colonized.

questions.question: During an influenza pandemic with limited N95 respirators, extended use means:
options: Wearing same respirator for multiple patient encounters without removal
questions.explanation: Extended use means wearing the same N95 respirator for multiple patient encounters without removing it between patients (but removing for breaks). Reuse means doffing and re-donning the same respirator.

questions.question: Your ICU has 3 AIIR rooms and 5 patients requiring airborne precautions (2 TB, 2 measles, 1 varicella). How should you prioritize room assignment?
options: TB patients get AIIRs; cohort measles patients; varicella in private room with N95 for all entering
All patients in regular rooms with N95
questions.explanation: Prioritize TB for AIIRs (highest transmission risk, longest duration). Cohort measles patients together (same pathogen, immune staff can care). Varicella in private room with N95 until AIIR available.

questions.question: A pregnant healthcare worker asks to be excused from caring for a patient with varicella. The MOST appropriate response is:
options: Refuse, all staff must provide care
Check immunity status; if non-immune, reassign to avoid exposure
Require N95 use regardless of immunity
questions.explanation: Check varicella immunity (history of disease or vaccination). Non-immune pregnant workers should be reassigned to avoid exposure due to risk of congenital varicella syndrome. Immune workers can safely provide care.

questions.question: Your facility is considering discontinuing contact precautions for endemic MRSA. What evidence should guide this decision?
options: Horizontal infection prevention measures (hand hygiene, environmental cleaning, stewardship) + surveillance data + risk assessment
questions.explanation: Decision requires: strong horizontal measures, sustained low MRSA rates, active surveillance, risk assessment by population, and multidisciplinary consensus. Some facilities successfully transitioned with robust programs.

questions.question: A patient with XDR-TB (extensively drug-resistant TB) requires transfer to another facility. What is the MOST critical step?
options: Notify receiving facility, arrange specialized transport with airborne precautions, and coordinate with public health
questions.explanation: XDR-TB transfer requires: advance notification to receiving facility, specialized transport with airborne precautions (negative pressure ambulance if available), N95 for patient and staff, and public health coordination.

questions.question: During a pandemic with PPE shortages, crisis capacity strategies include:
options: Extended use and limited reuse of N95s, prioritize PPE for high-risk procedures, consider alternatives (PAPRs, reusable elastomerics)
Use no PPE to conserve supplies
questions.explanation: Crisis capacity: extended use/limited reuse of N95s per CDC guidance, prioritize PPE for aerosol-generating procedures, consider alternatives (PAPRs, elastomeric respirators), and implement conservation strategies.

questions.question: A patient refuses to wear a mask despite having active TB. The MOST appropriate action is:
options: Educate patient, involve ethics committee, consider involuntary isolation if public health risk, and notify public health authorities
questions.explanation: Balance patient autonomy with public health protection: educate on risks, involve ethics committee, consider involuntary isolation as last resort per public health laws, and coordinate with health department.

questions.question: Your facility wants to implement universal gloving (gloves for all patient contact). What is the BEST approach?
options: Evaluate impact on hand hygiene compliance, cost, waste, and patient perception before implementation
Use gloves only for isolation patients
questions.explanation: Universal gloving may reduce hand hygiene compliance (false sense of security). Evaluate: hand hygiene rates, cost-effectiveness, environmental impact, patient perception, and ensure gloves don't replace hand hygiene.

questions.question: A novel pathogen emerges with 40% mortality and unknown transmission. Initial precautions should be:
options: Implement highest level precautions (contact + droplet + airborne) until transmission clarified
questions.explanation: Precautionary principle: implement highest level precautions (contact + droplet + airborne with PAPR) for novel high-mortality pathogens until transmission mode is clarified through epidemiologic investigation.

questions.question: Your hospital's MDRO rates are rising despite contact precautions. What is the MOST comprehensive approach?
options: Implement horizontal strategies: hand hygiene improvement, environmental cleaning enhancement, antimicrobial stewardship, active surveillance, and decolonization protocols
questions.explanation: Comprehensive MDRO prevention requires horizontal strategies: hand hygiene bundles, enhanced environmental cleaning, antimicrobial stewardship, active surveillance, decolonization (if appropriate), and contact precautions.

questions.question: As IPC Director, you must allocate limited isolation rooms during a multi-pathogen outbreak (CRE, C. difficile, influenza). What is the MOST evidence-based prioritization?
options: Prioritize based on transmission risk, severity, and availability of alternatives: CRE (highest priority), C. difficile (high priority), influenza (cohort if possible)
questions.explanation: Prioritize by transmission risk and consequences: CRE (highest - limited treatment, high mortality), C. difficile (high - environmental contamination), influenza (cohort immune-vaccinated staff). Use cohorting and enhanced cleaning.
